comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
PETER LYONS, 
MANUFACTURER OF 
PRIZE MEDAL BREAD 
AND CONFECTIONERY, 
OBTAINED 
Bronze Medal and Grand Diploma of Honour at Bakers' and 
Confectioners' International Exhibition, held in Koyal 
Agricultural Hall, London, 1896 ; 
ALSO OBTAINED 
Second Prize and 2 Diplomas for High Class Confectionery 
in open competition against all Confectioners in the 
United Kingdom, held in London, 1895.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Wonder did he win prizes later than 1896, or was he still living on the glory for a few years? (These Eason photos date from 1900 onwards...)

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The motor spirit sign would suggest that cars exist, so again, post-1896.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The Colman's poster would date it if you could just find a match. Their advertising changed a couple of times around 1900 with the move to the plainer font and the addition of "No. 1" and the bull.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I don't see the term "athlete carnival" in a newspaper search, these things seem to be reported as an "athletic carnival", or sometimes a "Gaelic League Athletic Carnival Ceilidh" (Irish Times Feb 1911).

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: What intrigues me about this picture is the many groups of well dressed men out side premises and hanging around the bridge. Is it a Sunday perhaps?

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] the census has James Bernard Clarke in West Street in 1901 but not in 1911 so that fits. You'd imagine that the sign over the door at least would have been changed if not the roof sign once the Clarke's emigrated to the US but the premises doesn't look very active. I wonder is that poster beside the door a notice of closure?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Carol, If you have that zoomy thing can you see what's on the postbox?  The monarchs name might tell a tale?  Great shot by the way, it is quite intruguing

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Hi Sean. Fired up our zoomy thing, but it's just not possible to make out any detail on the postbox, I'm afraid...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie]  Local histogram equalisation has the postbox saying VG or VC (well, actually it looks more like an upside down A). It's hard to tell because it's so small. Maybe Carol can do something with a combination of zooming and palette distortion.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Similarly, histogram faffing reveals stars in the background of the Colman's poster, which may help with the dating. I'm not sure if they were always present when the bull was or not.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: John Boyle is in the Bullring in the 1911 census, not the 1901.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I don't see Bennet of Bennet and Co in either census, though it appears to be a local business.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: newsfile.photoshelter.com/image/I000005QbFcLvFDA www.redbubble.com/people/munich/works/3924600-bull-ring-d... Didn't change much, did it?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] On the Victorian postboxes the stylised script does make the VR look like an A with embellishments.  See [http://www.flickr.com/photos/irelandseye/4748673520/] which illustrates that.  I was wondering if it was an Edwardian box it would bring the date forward a bit.  As regards your link to Photofile shot you are so right.  Apart from the cars there is very little changed in the shots!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] The side of that's more or less vertical. The one in the pic comes down at about 20 degrees off vertical. It looks like an upside down A. Looks like there's a crown above it too. To the extent that it looks like anything, it looks like the ER or GR emblem only with a V. The whole thing is only 8 pixels high though, so it wouldn't take much noise to swamp the signal.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] If it was an Edward VII pillar box (ie post 1901) then the cypher would look like this:

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] I don't think it's that. I'm becoming less convinced that it isn't just a scratch, though.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There seems to be no electric street lamps evident - anyone know when they arrived in Drogheda?  I tried to find out, but became completely enGoogled (technical term).

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Yorkshire Relish advert

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: the Colman's sign seems to be about 1900 ish, www.hantsphere.org.uk/ixbin/hixclient.exe?a=query&p=h... I found another wooden box using it as late as 1940.

comment.author: 80551708@N02
comment._content: Great to see some old photos of Drogheda, like going on a sentimental journey. Can see myself walking over the bridge in early sixties . Happy Xmas from Christchurch, NZ.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I was surprised that nobody commented on or put a note on the figure on the right foreground of the shot.  It looks to me like a clergyman in full battle regalia but it could also be an elderly lady in full dress.  The unusual thing is that he/she has an umbrella up in what appears to be a fine day with no sign of rain about?  Would it have been an indicator that the priest was bearing the eucharist or on an errand of mercy???
